sections.content: Understanding macronutrients—carbohydrates, proteins, and fats—is essential for optimizing your diet. Each plays distinct roles in energy production, tissue building, and overall health. The key is balance and choosing high-quality sources.

sections.title: Carbohydrates: fuel for performance
items: Complex carbs (whole grains, legumes, vegetables) provide sustained energy
Simple carbs (fruits, milk) offer quick energy with beneficial nutrients
Refined carbs (white bread, sugary snacks) cause blood sugar spikes
Aim for 45-65% of daily calories from quality carbohydrate sources

sections.title: Proteins: building blocks of life
items: Essential for muscle growth, repair, and immune function
Complete proteins contain all 9 essential amino acids
Animal sources: meat, fish, eggs, dairy
Plant sources: legumes, quinoa, soy, nuts, seeds
Aim for 0.8-1.2g per kg of body weight daily

sections.title: Fats: essential for health
items: Unsaturated fats (olive oil, avocados, nuts, fish) support heart health
Saturated fats (butter, red meat) should be consumed in moderation
Trans fats (fried foods, processed snacks) should be avoided
Fats should comprise 20-35% of daily calories

quiz.question: What percentage of daily calories should come from carbohydrates?
quiz.explanation: Health experts recommend that 45-65% of daily calories come from carbohydrates, primarily from whole food sources.

quiz.question: Which type of fat should be avoided?
quiz.explanation: Trans fats, found in many fried and processed foods, increase heart disease risk and should be avoided.

sections.content: Effective meal planning saves time, reduces food waste, supports healthy eating goals, and decreases reliance on processed convenience foods. It's a skill that becomes easier with practice and proper systems.

sections.title: Benefits of meal planning
items: Ensures balanced nutrition throughout the week
Reduces impulse eating and takeout expenses
Saves time during busy weekdays
Reduces food waste and grocery costs
Supports specific health or fitness goals

sections.title: Meal planning steps
items: Set aside 30 minutes weekly for planning
Review your schedule to identify busy days
Choose 3-5 recipes for the week
Create a detailed shopping list organized by store section
Prep ingredients in batches when possible
Use containers to portion and store meals

sections.title: Pro tips
items: Start simple with familiar recipes
Use a template to streamline planning
Build a rotation of go-to meals
Prep versatile ingredients (grilled chicken, roasted vegetables)
Leave one day for leftovers or flexibility

quiz.question: What is a key benefit of meal planning?
quiz.explanation: Meal planning helps ensure balanced nutrition throughout the week while saving time and money.

sections.content: Nutrition labels provide critical information about the foods you eat. Learning to read them effectively empowers you to make informed choices that align with your health goals.

sections.title: Key label components
items: Serving size: the amount all other numbers are based on
Calories: total energy provided per serving
Macronutrients: grams of fat, carbohydrates, and protein
% Daily Value: how much a nutrient contributes to a daily diet
Ingredient list: ingredients listed by weight, highest first

sections.title: What to watch for
items: Added sugars: aim for less than 25-36g daily
Sodium: keep under 2,300mg daily
Trans fats: should be 0g
Fiber: aim for at least 3g per serving in grain products
Ingredient lists: fewer ingredients usually means less processing

sections.content: Pay special attention to serving sizes—many packages contain multiple servings, so you need to multiply the label values if you consume the entire package.

quiz.question: What should be your daily limit for added sugars?
quiz.explanation: Health organizations recommend limiting added sugars to 25-36g per day for optimal health.

quiz.question: On a nutrition label, what does % Daily Value represent?
options: The percentage of the product that is organic
How much a nutrient contributes to a daily diet
quiz.explanation: % Daily Value shows how much of a specific nutrient one serving of the food contributes to a 2,000 calorie daily diet.
